column2: With enough on-chain data & public data (i.e. Twitter, personal websites, etc.), community chatbots will be better than community managers to drive individual engagement in large DAOs.

Peer verification systems also only work in a truly one-person one-vote system. Until we can prove uniqueness and set examples of DAOs that are Sybil resistant, any peer verification system is useless.

The more money it takes to verify someone (the more rewards given), the stronger the counter signal should be to the community about the quality of that verification. Having both the requester and verifiers data and rewards on-chain makes this all public.

The weaker a professional or social relationship is, the more material that needs to be introduced to compensate for the ‚Äúopportunity cost‚Äù. In a peer verification system, if I have a weak relationship with someone, but want their verification, I will send more rewards.

For some reason, we value the time of people we care about most the least. Ex: people are more afraid to waste 10 minutes of a strangers time over their moms. When we value time more, we feel a sense of ‚Äúguilt‚Äù when we take it away and provide gifts to make up for it.

If we introduce rewards for peer verification of off-chain tasks to build reputation, it should be clear that there is an inverse relationship between the verifiers rewards and quality of the verification. 

I explain more ‚¨áÔ∏è

to fund paradigm shifting work often means funding risky ideas which are less favored by consensus based models. small, aggressive, centralized, fast deployers of capital are far more efficient for high-risk high-reward projects.
if your funding science or public goods and your governance model is based on consensus decision-making, expect un-interesting and obvious outcomes.
@CharlieSandor 100% agree. My framing was more so apriori decentralization that we do not need to unnecessarily design for this composability yet.

Sometimes it feels like Web3 protocol designers are building for themselves. I personally find it elegant to have this freedom, but most people don't care. People don't ask if Facebook uses MySQL or PostgreSQL, they ask if they can message their friends.
The ability for people to choose where their data is stored  (i.e, Arweave , Amazon S3, or @IPFS) is over-rated. If people cared about data sovereignty, we would see worse symptoms of it already.
@divine_economy making the cost of action so much more sensitive if done wrong. this leads to a place of more fear for most people.

To everyone working in this space, keep it up! Let's remember this is a positive sum game and we can work together to make this truly solve some of the most pressing coordination problems today by doing so.

The fears with putting on-chain identity need to be recognized as we build: 
- privacy and transparency tradeoffs
- alignment and "day one" person loss
- cost of actions
- trajectory towards quantifying humans worth

8/8 AGGREGATORS

Individual assets, transactions, and participation in Web3 communities are done across multiple wallets and chains. This fragmentation will continue to increase with creation of networked products that are not exclusively built on bluechip infrastructure. https://t.co/qINHez4hBg

7/8 DATA RAILS

Individuals have control over the discovery, sharing, and permissions of their data. Individuals can choose how their data is stored (on traditional DB or blockchain datastores). https://t.co/Dj4yoEKLAO

6/8 PROOF OF HUMANITY 

With a protocol that is sybil resistant, we unlock: the ability to democratically vote; trust quadratic votes; build trustworthy reputation systems; and fund public goods at a larger scale. https://t.co/fStARsEHDZ

5/8 PROFILES

The ability to showcase competency, worth, or status is not new to Web3, but doing so with blockchain technology, enables the network to view profiles from the lens of verification instead of the lens of trust. https://t.co/SQcggqG6Lv

4/8 BOUNTIES

The most useful case for bounties is onboarding. It is in the best interest of individuals who are looking to unlock maximum rewards to have their on-chain reputation be as strong as possible. https://t.co/22CpPJI7xy

3/8 GOVERNANCE

When we think about who we may want to delegate our tokens to, or who to hire for community growth and engagement, governance data can be useful to guide decision making in these contexts. https://t.co/cpleQdJnJA

2/8 OWNERSHIP 

Objective data is the easiest information to capture on-chain and associated with an individual's identity (ex. transactions, NFTs owned, and other crypto assets) via a wallets history. https://t.co/t4m7LU9HMt

1/8 ENDORSEMENT

The more human focused a DAO is, the more off-chain activity there is. The ability to connect the off-chain and on-chain data in a verified way to present one's professional identity is missing in current Web3 tooling infrastructure. https://t.co/8sl7op3BAB
There are 30+ teams working in this space. The on-chain identity landscape of 2022. https://t.co/mPM9t9Uonn

On-chain reputation is going to transform human coordination. 

Breaking down the on-chain identity landscape üîΩ

5. These results oracles and retroactive funding models do not need to be exclusively used for public good funding but can also be used to change investment behavior in DAOs that focus on early stage investment.

4. Contributors should be made aware of a ‚Äúresults oracle‚Äù that protocols have created to reward projects retroactively for their utility. Individuals become more risk tolerant as the expected return changes dramatically with the results protocol in place.

3. Low-risk projects are often in the best interest of the public to contribute to for individual expected return. Quadratic funding models favor low-risk proposals as matched donations are dependent on consensus from the most number of people. https://t.co/oxN67PEhyu

2. To push the frontiers of human progress, ARPA styled agencies understand the importance of funding high-risk high-reward projects. The decisions are made in a centralized manner, making it easier to support risk and expedite time to fund.

1. Current decentralized funding models don't favor high-risk high-reward proposals. To solve human coordination failures, we need to fund risky projects. A results oracle for retroactive funding will change contribution behavior to enable this.
